revision.comment: /* External links */ remove excessive social networking, indirect websites, and blogs, per [[WP:ELMINOFFICIAL]]/[[WP:NOT#REPOSITORY]]/[[WP:EL#EL11]]/[[WP:EL#EL13]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Sasha Matthews | image = Sasha-Matthews-Pyramid-Gang.jpg | caption = Sasha Matthews | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|2004|8|24}} | birth_place = New York City | nationality = [[United States|American]] | notable_works = {{Plainlist| * ''Everyday Superheroes'' * ''Steve Harvey: The Life of Steve Harvey'' * ''Pompeii: Lost and Found'' * ''Sitting Bull: A Life Story'' }} | awards = | website = http://rumblecomics.com }}
'''Sasha Matthews''' is a [[cartoonist]], [[Activism|activist]], and 8th grader living in [[New York City]].
==Activism==
===''Everyday Superheroes'' Fundraiser for ACLU===
From early 2017 through early 2018 Matthews worked on a fundraiser for the [[American Civil Liberties Union]]. Her idea was to represent everyday people doing what they do in everyday life, but in the iconic form of a superhero. She called this project ''Everyday Superheroes.'' In the end she completed 95 commissioned drawings and collected $11,635.83, which she presented to ACLU President [[Susan Herman]] at the ACLU headquarters in downtown Manhattan.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.westsiderag.com/2017/11/19/local-13-year-old-gives-aclu-11635-83-earned-from-her-everyday-superhero-drawings|title=Local 13-Year-Old Gives ACLU $11,635.83, Earned from Her 'Everyday Superhero' Drawings}}</ref> Along the way Matthews' ''Everyday Superheroes'' earned recognition from United States Senator [[Kamala Harris]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/KamalaHarris/status/841095968498036737|title=Kamala Harris on Twitter|work=twitter.com}}</ref> and was written about by [[Amy Poehler]]'s [[Amy_Poehler%27s_Smart_Girls|Smart Girls]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://amysmartgirls.com/meet-sasha-matthews-teen-artist-who-has-raised-almost-10-000-for-the-aclu-a21444d3f4f|title=Meet Sasha Matthews, Teen Artist Who Has Raised Almost $10,000 for the ACLU}}</ref> [[HuffPost|Huffington Post]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/girl-raises-more-than-2000-for-the-aclu-with-everyday-superheroes-art_us_58c086b5e4b0d1078ca3c036|title=Girl Raises More Than $2,000 For The ACLU With 'Everyday Superheroes' Art|first=Taylor|last=Pittman|date=9 March 2017|publisher=|via=Huff Post}}</ref> [[Ashton Kutcher]]'s [[A_Plus_(aplus.com)|A Plus]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aplus.com/a/sasha-matthews-everyday-superheroes-drawings-aclu|title=This 12-Year-Old Girl's Comic Series Shows That Everyone Is A Superhero No Matter What|date=20 March 2017|work=aplus.com}}</ref> [[DNAinfo]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20170308/upper-west-side/donation-commission-illustrations-superheroes-aclu-sasha-harmon-matthews|title=12-Year-Old Cartoonist's 'Everyday Superheroes' Help Raise Money for ACLU|work=dnainfo.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322044022/https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20170308/upper-west-side/donation-commission-illustrations-superheroes-aclu-sasha-harmon-matthews|archivedate=2017-03-22|df=}}</ref> and West Side Rag.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westsiderag.com/2017/02/27/12-year-old-local-artist-creates-everyday-superheroes-to-raise-money-for-the-aclu|title=12-Year-Old Local Artist Creates 'Everyday Superheroes’ to Raise Money for the ACLU|work=westsiderag.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.westsiderag.com/2017/11/19/local-13-year-old-gives-aclu-11635-83-earned-from-her-everyday-superhero-drawings|title=Local 13-Year-Old Gives ACLU $11,635.83, Earned from Her ‘Everyday Superhero’ Drawings|work=westsiderag.com}}</ref> ACLU President [[Susan Herman]] went on to commission an ''Everyday Superhero'' portrait of herself<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rumblecomics.com/everyday-superheroes/susan-herman|title=Susan Herman Everyday Superhero by Rumble Comics|work=rumblecomics.com}}</ref> and another of ACLU Executive Director [[Anthony Romero]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rumblecomics.com/everyday-superheroes/anthony-romero|title=Anthony Romero Everyday Superhero by Rumble Comics|work=rumblecomics.com}}</ref>
===Scholastic Art & Writing Awards===
The [[Scholastic_Corporation|Scholastic]] [[Alliance_for_Young_Artists_%26_Writers|Art & Writing Awards]] recognize creative achievements of teenagers in grades 7-12. In 2018, nearly 350,000 works were submitted for consideration.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.artandwriting.org/what-we-do/the-awards/|title=The Awards}}</ref> Matthews had intended to submit her ''Everyday Superheroes'' project under the Civic Expression category, for work that "expresses a vision of the society they are working to build, one that exemplifies democratic values and that allows all voices and viewpoints to be heard and respected."
Before she submitted her work, Matthews read the Terms & Conditions and discovered that the Scholastic Art & Writing Awards were claiming ownership of kids' copyrights. She highlighted the questionable text and tweeted a question.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/RumbleComics/status/940691277166927872|title=Rumble Comics on Twitter}}</ref> She didn't receive a sensible response, so she wrote a cartoon about the situation and tweeted it.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/RumbleComics/status/944192049833791489|title=Rumble Comics on Twitter}}</ref> Still no response, so next Matthews wrote up the experience for an 8th grade homework assignment. This report was then published by web site [[Boing_Boing|Boing Boing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://boingboing.net/2018/02/08/terms-and-conditions-apply.html|title=How a kid cartoonist avoided Scholastic's digital sharecropping trap}}</ref> As a result, the Scholastic Art & Writing Awards announced their intention to revise their Terms before the upcoming 2019 contest. This outcome was written about by [[Hyperallergic]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hyperallergic.com/433005/kid-cartoonist-pushes-scholastic-art-contest-reconsider-copyright-policy/|title=Kid Cartoonist Pushes Scholastic Art Contest to Reconsider Its Copyright Policy}}</ref> Danish national newspaper [[Politiken]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/RumbleComics/status/981551991166992384|title=Rumble Comics on Twitter}}</ref> [[AM_New_York|AM New York]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amny.com/news/scholastic-awards-sasha-matthews-1.17127599|title=Manhattan teen cartoonist prompts review of Scholastic awards’ copyright rules}}</ref> and Boing Boing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://boingboing.net/2018/03/12/after-copyright-wrangle-schol.html|title=After copyright wrangle, Scholastic promises better deal for competition entrants}}</ref>
===Editorial Cartooning===
Matthews responded to the [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]] with a series of editorial cartoons, which were then written about by web site [[Hyperallergic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hyperallergic.com/432442/sasha-matthews-cartoonist-parkland-shooting/|title=How a 13-Year-Old Cartoonist Responded to the Parkland School Shooting}}</ref> Previously Matthews had responded to the [[Unite the Right rally]] in Charlottesville, which was written about by web site The Mary Sue.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.themarysue.com/charlottesville-cartoon-by-rumble-comics/|title=Our Favorite 12-Year-Old Cartoonist Had the Perfect Response to Trump and Charlottesville}}</ref>
===Marvel Comics & Internet Trolls===
Matthews took a stand when a group of conservative [[Internet_troll|Internet trolls]] began attacking a group of women working at [[Marvel Comics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/books/news/female-marvel-comics-editor-harassed-online-milkshake-selfie/|title=Female Marvel Comics editor harassed online for milkshake selfie}}</ref> Conservative pundit [[Michelle_Malkin|Michelle Malkin]] wound up publicly siding with Matthews<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/michellemalkin/status/892874887211212800|title=Michelle Malkin on Twitter}}</ref> and the whole incident was covered by web site The Mary Sue.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.themarysue.com/the-case-of-the-12-year-old-brilliant-cartoonist/|title=A 12-Year-Old Cartoonist Got Trolled For Her Social Justice Views (So Let’s Help Her Out)}}</ref>
==Published works==
Matthews has authored and self-published four comic books: ''Everyday Superheroes'' (2018),<ref name="Bookculture">{{cite web|url=http://www.bookculture.com/search/author/%22Matthews,%20Sasha%22|title=Search for Author: "Matthews, Sasha" - Book Culture|work=bookculture.com}}</ref> ''Steve Harvey: The Life of Steve Harvey'' (2016),<ref name="Bookculture">{{cite web|url=http://www.bookculture.com/search/author/%22Matthews,%20Sasha%22|title=Search for Author: "Matthews, Sasha" - Book Culture|work=bookculture.com}}</ref> ''Pompeii: Lost and Found'' (2015),<ref name="Bookculture" /> and ''Sitting Bull: A Life Story'' (2015).<ref name="Bookculture" />
Matthews' comic books have been written about by Tech Times,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/75245/20150813/portrait-comics-artist-young-girl-interview-sasha-matthews.htm|title=Portrait Of A Comics Artist As A Young Girl: An Interview With Sasha Matthews|first=Tech|last=Times|date=13 August 2015|work=techtimes.com}}</ref> Bleeding Cool,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bleedingcool.com/2015/08/14/our-first-ten-year-old-comic-book-publisher-sasha-matthews/|title=Is Sasha Matthews The First Ten Year Old Proper Comic Book Publisher?|date=14 August 2015|work=bleedingcool.com}}</ref> Book Culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bookculture.com/blog/2015/04/17/interview-sasha-matthews-author-sitting-bull-life-story|title=Interview with Sasha Matthews, author of "Sitting Bull: A Life Story" - Book Culture|work=bookculture.com}}</ref> Fumettologica (Italian),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fumettologica.it/2015/08/sasha-matthews-fumettista-dieci-anni/|title=Avere 10 anni, una casa editrice e 3 fumetti pubblicati - Fumettologica|date=17 August 2015|work=fumettologica.it}}</ref> and Women Write About Comics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://womenwriteaboutcomics.com/2016/02/16/make-your-own-comic-101-with-sasha-matthews/|title=Eleven Year Old Sasha Matthews Could Teach You A Thing Or Two About Making Comics|date=16 February 2016|work=womenwriteaboutcomics.com}}</ref>
Matthews publishes under the name Rumble Comics, a reference to the erupting volcano in ''Pompeii: Lost and Found.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rumblecomics.com|title=Rumble Comics by Sasha Matthews|work=rumblecomics.com}}</ref>
===''Everyday Superheroes''===
Between 2017 and 2018 Matthews worked on a fundraiser for the American Civil Liberties Union, creating 95 commissioned drawings and raising $11,635.83 total. She collected 48 of her favorites to make her fourth self-published comic. The comic book version of Everyday Superheroes was introduced at Book Culture alongside cartoonist R. Sikoryak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bookculture.com/event/columbus-r-sikoryak-and-sasha-matthews|title=Columbus: R. Sikoryak and Sasha Matthews}}</ref>
===''Steve Harvey: The Life of Steve Harvey''===
Matthews was invited to appeared on NBC's Little Big Shots. For her appearance she wrote a new biographical comic about the host, Steve Harvey.
===''Pompeii: Lost and Found''===
Her second comic, "Pompeii: Lost and Found," was introduced at a joint book event with [[The_New_York_Times_Best_Seller_list|New York Times bestselling author]] [[George O'Connor (comics)|George O'Connor]] of the ''Olympians'' series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bookculture.com/event/columbus-sasha-matthews-george-oconnor|title=Columbus: Sasha Matthews & George O'Connor - Book Culture|work=bookculture.com}}</ref> ''Pomeii: Lost and Found'' was recognized by Massimo Osanna, Head of Archaeology at [[Pompeii]], [[Herculaneum]], and [[Stabiae]], for attention to historical and cultural detail.
===''Sitting Bull: A Life Story''===
Her first comic, ''Sitting Bull: A Life Story'' was originally published by [[Boing Boing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2015/02/27/comic-the-life-of-sitting-bul.html|title=Comic: The Life of Sitting Bull, as told by a 10-year-old|work=boingboing.net}}</ref> [[Mark Frauenfelder]], co-editor of Boing Boing, favorably compared her work to that of a young [[Robert Crumb]].
==Television appearances==
===Microsoft 3D Holiday===
Microsoft modeled their 2017/2018 holiday campaign on Matthews. Their fictionalized and animated character, also named Sasha, uses her art in support of inclusion and making the world a better place. The commercial transitions to the real Sasha at the end.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QVtgtJQ8AZM|title=3D Holiday: Microsoft TV Commercial}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/creativity/microsofts-3d-holiday-ad-is-a-whimsical-out-of-earth-inclusion-parable/|title=Microsoft's '3D Holiday' Ad Is a Whimsical, Out-of-Earth Inclusion Parable}}</ref>
===NBC's Little Big Shots===
In 2017 Matthews appeared on [[NBC]]'s [[Little Big Shots]] (S2 E5) as the show's first author/artist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j75cqZqLzqU|title=Little Big Shots - Steve Harvey's Life as a Comic Book (Episode Highlight)|first=|last=Little Big Shots|date=2 April 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/little-big-shots/video/tugging-on-the-harp-strings/3489400|title=Tugging on the Harp Strings|date=3 April 2017|work=nbc.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/little-big-shots/video/steve-harveys-life-as-a-comic-book/3493004|title=Steve Harvey's Life as a Comic Book|date=2 April 2017|work=nbc.com}}</ref> For her appearance she wrote a new biographical comic about the host, [[Steve Harvey]], using [[Wikipedia]] as a reference. [[Ellen DeGeneres]], a co-producer of Little Big Shots, also has a cameo in the comic. The segment was taped July, 2016 at [[Warner_Bros._Studios,_Burbank|Warner Bros. Studios]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.warnerbros.com/tv/little-big-shots|title=Little Big Shots: Season 2|work=warnerbros.com}}</ref>
==Awards==
===NYC Council Citation===
Matthews received a Citation from the New York City Council in May, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.michaelpalma.com/Mark-Levine-2017/i-hcG6DVC|title=Sasha Matthews receives Citation from New York City Council}}</ref>
===Crain's 20 Under 20===
Crain's named Matthews as one of their 20 Under 20 for 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/section/20under20/2017/3480400/sasha-matthews|title=Upper West Side, Cartoonist/free-speech activist}}</ref>
==Public speaking==
===ACLU Conference=== On May 10, 2018 Matthews will be a speaker at the ACLU Conference in Washington, DC.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://conference.aclu.org/|title=ACLU Conference}}</ref>
===Nasty Women Unite Festival=== On June 5, 2018 Matthews was a panelist at the Nasty Women Unite Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nastywomenunitefest.com/2018lineup/|title=Nasty Women Unite Festival 2018 Lineup}}</ref>
===Clara Lemlich Awards 2018=== On May 1, 2018 Matthews was a presenter at the [[Clara Lemlich]] Awards held at the [[Museum of the City of New York]]. The awards honor women in their 80s, 90s, and 100s for lifetimes of activism. Matthews will introduce honoree Doreen Wohl, retired Executive Director of the West Side Campaign Against Hunger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcny.org/event/eighth-annual-clara-lemlich-awards|title=The Eighth Annual Clara Lemlich Awards}}</ref>
===Girl Up New York Leadership Summit 2018=== On April 29, 2018 Matthews was a keynote speaker at the Girl Up New York Leadership Summit in New York City. Following her presentation, she sat on a discussion panel with [[American Civil Liberties Union]] president [[Susan Herman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.girlupnewyork.org/summit/|title=Girl Up New York Leadership Summit}}</ref> Girl Up is the [[United Nations Foundation]]'s adolescent girl campaign, which engages girls to take action.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://girlup.org/about/|title=About Girl Up}}</ref>
===Women's March 2018===
Matthews was invited to speak at a rally at the 2018 Women's March in New York City. She spoke following New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nyclu.org/en/press-releases/thousands-join-nyclu-rally-rights-and-equality-womens-march-nyc|title=Thousands Join NYCLU Rally For Rights and Equality at Women’s March On NYC}}</ref>
===Clara Lemlich Awards 2017===
On May 1, 2017 Matthews was a presenter at the [[Clara Lemlich]] Awards held at the [[Museum of the City of New York]]. The awards honor women in their 80s, 90s, and 100s for lifetimes of activism. Matthews introduced honoree Ingrid Frank, a [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]] survivor who then worked for 75 years for [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcny.org/event/seventh-annual-clara-lemlich-awards|title=The Seventh Annual Clara Lemlich Awards}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
